title: Trump and Brexit: the establishment is hitting back
text:
Tuesday, September 24 will be remembered as the day that old political empires struck back in London and Washington.

The British Parliament and the country’s Supreme Court have dealt a heavy blow to Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s Brexit project, rejecting his attempt to prorogue Parliament and curb crucial days of debate. Hours later in Washington, the House of Representatives said it would begin an impeachment inquiry not just against alleged pressure on Ukraine to investigate the son of Donald Trump's rival Joe Biden but effectively against Mr Trump’s whole presidency and outsize persona. After years of populist uprising and insurgent politics, the establishment has reasserted itself.

Regardless of their wisdom, the Trump presidency and the Brexit referendum were great popular revolts against globalisation, in the British case the biggest vote for anything in its history. But US and British elites and institutions have never accepted any of these results. Brexit pitched a popular plebiscite against a sovereign Parliament and left the legislature too bitterly divided to enact a departure from the European Union. The battles have stretched political processes, decorum and tradition to their limits. Mr Trump and Mr Johnson use shock to attract voters tired of business as usual. The US President has turned doubling down on outrageous behaviour into a White House new normal. That always made it likely that he would carelessly blunder into some trap that he finally could not escape from, and which may dominate the rest of his first term. In Britain, it has brought a deep crisis, with a messy unwritten constitution dependent on precedent and gentlemen’s agreements that is unable to handle this level of chicanery and conflict. As the Supreme Court rules against Mr Johnson’s proroguing of Parliament, each side has claimed the other has inflicted an undemocratic constitutional coup on the nation.

President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Boris Johnson are facing down the moves against them. New York Times

In practical terms, Britain now has a government absurdly short of majority, unable to act, and held in place only because its opponents can’t accept Opposition Leader Jeremy Corbyn as caretaker prime minister if they win a no-confidence vote. Or because they fear losing the subsequent general election, leading to a restored Johnson prime ministership, which current polls say is still quite achievable. But Labour want to keep Mr Johnson dangling there, while they push the date of a fait accompli Brexit which would favour the Prime Minister, further and further away from him with new delays. But amidst all the sound and fury, Mr Johnson needs to focus only on one thing: that the biggest, most stable bloc of voters are Leavers.

Each side’s media in the US and Britain have descended into rival narratives of treacherous elites and ignorant voters. But elites cannot wish away election results they don’t like. Mr Johnson will now campaign in terms of the people versus Parliament, once a contradiction in terms in Britain. Mr Trump will similarly use impeachment proceedings as a stage to target the hypocrisy of the Biden family and the Democrats, just as he did so successfully against the Clintons before the 2016 election.
description: Elites are resisting two crash-through politicians. But populist revolts also have deep roots.
